questionText: How will the American people verify the calculations behind the Census Bureau’s differentially private data?
answerMD:
The Census Bureau will release the exact software used to compute the differentially private publication data, all of the components associated with the disclosure avoidance system, and the privacy parameter values. This is the same standard of assurance that has been widely adopted to verify the security of cryptographic algorithms and implementations.  

See also:  [Statistical Safeguards](https://www.census.gov/about/policies/privacy/statistical_safeguards.html "Statistical Safeguards")

questionText: How can I tell if the respondent was the reference person in the American Housing Survey (AHS) public use file (PUF)?
answerMD:
The reference person is used to order the relationships among the persons in the household; the respondent is the person who answered the questions in the AHS interview.  
  

1.  In 1997 and later surveys, to determine if the reference person and the respondent are the same:

*   If DLINE1=PLINE and for that person REL=1 or REL=2, then the respondent is the household reference person.
*   If DLINE1=PLINE and REL>2 then the respondent is not the household reference person.
*   You can identify the relationship of the respondent based on the REL variable.
*   If DLINE1=B (so no one living in the unit), then check RESPTYP, and that will report the type of respondent.  
      
    

3.  In surveys, before 1997, there is no RESPTYP. Instead, DLINE1 contains special codes if the respondent is not the reference person. This will occur only for vacant or URE interviews (ISTATUS not equal to 1).

questionText: In the United States Constitution, the census is required for the apportionment of representatives; why does the ACS ask for more than just the number of people in a home?
answerMD:
The United States Constitution states that "\[An\] Enumeration shall be made within three Years after the first Meeting of the Congress of the United States, and within every subsequent Term of ten Years, in such Manner as they shall by Law direct." Pursuant to this constitutional directive, Congress passed separate laws for each decennial census and specified the information to be collected. In 1954, Congress codified earlier census acts and all other statutes authorizing the decennial census as Title 13, United States Code (U.S.C.). From the very first census act, Congress sought the collection of more information than just a headcount. 

Because the American Community Survey (ACS) is part of the Decennial Census Program, it is governed by the same laws as the census. The current legal authority for collecting these data resides in Title 13 of the U.S.C. or the "Census Act." The Census Act provides the Census Bureau with legal authority to conduct the decennial census and delegates broad discretionary authority to the Secretary of Commerce for determining the manner of conducting the census. This authority has been redelegated by the Secretary to the Director of the Census Bureau.

Even though Congress has granted this broad discretionary authority, the questions asked in the Census and ACS are determined by what data are needed to implement a vast array of federal programs. Courts routinely have upheld the constitutionality of collecting census data, characterizing as unquestionable the power of Congress to require both an enumeration and the collection of statistics in the census.

The Courts have held that the Constitution, including the Fifth and Fourth Amendments, does not prohibit the gathering of other statistics in addition to the enumeration.

questionText: In TIGERweb, there are four choices at the top of the Map Layers window: Current, ACS 20xx, ACS 20yy and Census 2010. How do I know which one to use?
answerMD:
The four choices at the top of the Map Layers window refer to TIGER benchmarks, which are snapshots of the data in the MAF/TIGER database. The Geography Division creates two benchmarks each year, one in May and another in September. The benchmark created in May is known as the American Community Survey (ACS) benchmark because the boundaries in it are used to tabulate the ACS data. Because it takes a while to tabulate the ACS data, the geographic boundaries are usually available to the public about a year before the release of the statistical data. This is why there are two vintages related to the ACS available in TIGERweb. The more recent layer includes the most current ACS boundaries available. The older one includes the boundaries used in the tabulation of the most recently available ACS data. New ACS vintages are usually added to TIGERweb in the fall of each year.

There is also a Current layer in TIGERweb. As mentioned above, the Geography Division creates a second yearly benchmark of TIGER each September, which is known as the Boundary and Annexation Survey (BAS) benchmark. Data from this benchmark is used for some of our partnership programs, such as the BAS. Layers from the BAS benchmark are usually added to TIGERweb late each winter. This means that for half of the year, the "Current" layer will match the most recent ACS layer. For the other half of the year though, the "Current" layer will represent the BAS benchmark. Therefore, if you just want to view the most recent geographic data, use the Current layer. If you are looking at boundaries in relation to ACS data though, you should use one of the two ACS layers.

Finally, there is also a 2010 layer in the version of TIGERweb. This layer represents the boundaries that were in effect in 2010, but shows them as they appear in the most recent benchmark. This means that it includes updates made since 2010 to linear features such as roads. For example, if a road has been reshaped and it forms the boundary of a geographic area, then the reshaped boundary will be displayed. To view the 2010 boundaries as they were in 2010, use the TIGERweb Decennial version of the application, available from the TIGERweb homepage.

questionText: What determines the size of the annual revisions?
answerMD:
The size of the revision for the unadjusted estimates is based on revisions between the results of the most recent Annual Retail Trade Survey and the previously published estimates derived from the monthly survey.

For more information, visit the [Monthly and Annual Retail Trade](http://www.census.gov/retail/index.html) website.

questionText: How will the new methods impact characteristic data, such as race and ethnicity, required to build districts in compliance with the Voting Rights Act? The margins for that data can be very small.
answerMD: Traditional disclosure avoidance methods, such as swapping, always impacted the actual numbers for characteristics such as race and ethnicity. By design, data users didn’t have the information needed to assess whether the extent of the noise infusion impacted their research inferences. The new method will provide that information. The published census data will be the official data.

questionText: How does the American Housing Survey (AHS) public use file (PUF) identify the person data for the spouse of the householder?
answerMD: The best way is to check REL (REL1-REL16 in the flat file) for a value of 20.   That record (or variable set) will be the spouse.

questionText: What data will the redistricting release contain?
answerMD:
The August data release will provide the first look at the demographic characteristics of the nation by state, county, city, all the way down to the census block level, including:

*   Race and ethnicity.
*   Population 18 years and over.
*   Occupied and vacant housing units.
*   People living in group quarters like nursing homes, prisons, military barracks and college dorms.

questionText: Is there a required action from the respondent for the Group Quarters Enumeration for the 2018 Census Test?
answerMD: Yes, a respondent is required to participate in the 2018 Census Test by completing the census questionnaire or eResponse template. The Census Bureau will collect respondent data using the enumeration methods identified in question 8 below for each individual living or staying at a group quarters.

questionText: How did the Census Bureau involve data users in the design of the Disclosure Avoidance System (DAS)?
answerMD:
The U.S. Census Bureau’s Data Stewardship Executive Policy Committee (DSEP) relies on input from a variety of sources when making decisions about the adoption, implementation, and parameters of the DAS. These include internal subject matter experts, the Census Bureau’s advisory panels (the National Advisory Committee on Racial, Ethnic, and Other Populations and the Census Scientific Advisory Committee), the Committee on National Statistics of the National Academy of Sciences, academic experts and researchers, privacy advocates, professional associations, federal and state partners (including the DOJ with regards to Voting Rights Act matters), and many others.  

We also solicited public comments in a July 2018 Federal Register notice and have conducted formal consultations with American Indian and Alaska Native tribal leaders.  

Engagement with these and other stakeholders is ongoing. The Census Bureau will continue to solicit and consider feedback to improve our disclosure avoidance methods. This process of enhanced data user engagement in the design and implementation of disclosure avoidance methods marks a significant shift from prior censuses, where data users were largely unaware of the impact of the methods being applied.

questionText: How are the ACS and 2020 Census different?
answerMD:
The 2020 Census counts each person in the U.S., where they live on April first.  The decennial census happens every ten years ending in zero.  
Unlike the decennial census, the American Community Survey is an ongoing survey that only collects information from selected addresses.  The American Community Survey asks questions that are not on the census.  This includes education, employment, and transportation, and provides communities with up-to-date data every year.

questionText: How much time will I have to become compliant with the new Foreign Trade Regulations (FTR)?
answerMD: The requirements under the new FTR are effective July 2, 2008, 30 days after the publication date. The effective date means all provisions in the FTR should be observed. However, the Census Bureau is providing an additional 90 days, until September 30, 2008, to allow the trade community to come into compliance with the requirements. Until September 30, 2008 informed compliance is in effect. Starting October 1, 2008, enforced compliance takes effect and fines and penalties for violations of the FTR may be imposed.

questionText: How are the American Community Survey (ACS) and 2020 Census different?
answerMD:
The 2020 Census counts each person in the U.S., where they live on April first.  The decennial census happens every ten years ending in zero.

Unlike the decennial census, the American Community Survey is an ongoing survey that only collects information from selected addresses.  The American Community Survey asks questions that are not on the census.  This includes education, employment, and transportation, and provides communities with up-to-date data every year.

answerMD: Service-Based Enumeration for the 2018 Census Test will study respondent information collection using the individual census questionnaire, procedures to prevent duplication of records of individuals, and determine the number of staff needed for this effort in the 2020 Census.

questionText: Does the Census Bureau have Monthly Retail Trade Survey estimates of sales and inventories for the affected areas?
answerMD:
No. We cannot separately quantify the impact on the affected areas because the MRTS is designed to estimate for sales and inventories at the United States level only.

For more information, visit the [Monthly and Annual Retail Trade](http://www.census.gov/retail/index.html) website.

questionText: Where can I find an update to the Taxable Property Values survey?
answerMD:
The Property Values Survey consisted of two components: The Assessment/ Sales Price Ratio Study and the Distribution of the Taxable Base by Use. The history:

*   Both phases were last done in 1982.
    
*   In 1987, only the phase dealing with the Distribution of the Taxable Base was conducted.
    
*   In 1992, we only published the assessed value aggregates (without distribution by use).
    
*   After 1992 the Census Bureau discontinued data collection in this topical area.
    

Although most state governments continue to collect assessment data and to publish ratio studies, there has been no effort to present these various efforts in a national framework..

questionText: How do I apply for a job to work on the 2015 Census Test in the Savannah media market?
answerMD: The Census Bureau will not be hiring anyone to conduct the field work for the 2015 Test in the Savannah media market test site because this is a test only studying ways to increase self-response. We will not be conducting in-person visits to households who do not respond to the test.

questionText: What is the difference between the variables NOPROB and NPROBS in the American Housing Survey (AHS) public use file (PUF)?
answerMD:
NPROBS provides a yes/no response to the question "Is there <anything/anything else> about the neighborhood that bothers you?"  It is asked after the respondent was asked about heavy traffic, neighborhood crime, smoke/gas or bad smells, and street noise.  
  
If the person answers 'yes' to NPROBS they have an opportunity to indicate all that apply from the following list, which includes the variable NOPROB:  
  

No problem

NOPROB

Noise

NOISE

Litter or housing deterioration

LITTER

Poor city/county services

BADSRV

Undesirable commercial, institutional, or industrial property

BADPRP

People

BADPER

Other

OTHNHD

   
If someone says, "Yes, there is something about the neighborhood that bothers me," he can then say, "no problem."

questionText: What is the difference between the variables PRENT and RENT in the American Housing Survey (AHS) public use file (PUF)?
answerMD: RENT is contract rent, but PRENT is what the household actually pays. The difference occurs when a unit is subsidized in some way (and thus the government or some other entity pays part of the contract rent). If you are interested in household expenditures, use PRENT if it has an entry. If you are interested in the cost of a unit independent of who lives there, use RENT.

questionText: What was the impact of altering the seasonal adjustment option for the September and October 2001 data months?
answerMD:
The option ensured that the magnitudes and directions of the seasonal adjustments of September, October, and surrounding months were consistent with the magnitudes and directions of the adjustments for these same calendar months in the recent past.

For more information, visit the [Monthly and Annual Retail Trade](http://www.census.gov/retail/index.html) website.

questionText: How has NAICS industry classification changed since the 2002 Economic Census?
answerMD:
Only [six](http://www.census.gov/eos/www/naics/faqs/faqs.html#q14) of the twenty NAICS sectors had changes during the 2007 revision of NAICS.

The [2007 Bridge Report](http://factfinder2.census.gov/bkmk/navigation/1.0/en/text_search:EC0700CBDG*) shows the effect of the classification changes on the data. For the effect of changes that took place in 2002, see the [2002 Bridge Statistics](http://factfinder2.census.gov/bkmk/navigation/1.0/en/text_search:EC0200CBDG*).

Two files are available that map the complete concordance of 2002 to 2007 NAICS codes, and vice versa:

*   [2007 NAICS U.S. Matched to 2002 NAICS U.S.](http://www.census.gov/eos/www/naics/concordances/2007_to_2002_NAICS.xls) \[XLS\]
*     
    
*   [2002 NAICS U.S. Matched to 2007 NAICS U.S.](http://www.census.gov/eos/www/naics/concordances/2002_to_2007_NAICS.xls) \[XLS\]

questionText: What is the Advance Monthly Retail Trade Survey sample revision?
answerMD:
The Census Bureau periodically redesigns and reselects the samples for its business surveys to reflect the results of the latest Economic Census. The Advance Monthly Retail Trade Survey is being revised to reflect the 2002 Economic Census of Retail Trade and more recent data from the Business Register. This ensures that our sample is representative of the current retail industry. Revising the sample also allows the Census Bureau to redistribute the burden of reporting for small and medium sized companies.

For more information, visit the [Monthly and Annual Retail Trade](http://www.census.gov/retail/index.html) website.

questionText: Is there a difference between the reference person and the householder in the American Housing Survey (AHS)?
answerMD: No. "Reference person" is a survey research term that means the person to whom all other persons in the surveyed entity are compared. In the AHS, this "entity" is the household. "Householder" is an economic term that means the person who has legal responsibility for the decisions of a household. The AHS uses the householder as the reference person. Note that there may be more than one person who can be considered the householder, as when there is more than one person named on the lease or title. In that case, the AHS accepts any such person as the householder.

questionText: What was the average number of people per representative based on the 2010 Census apportionment?
answerMD: After the apportionment based on the 2010 Census, the average number of people per representative in the House was 710,767. For more information, please see [apportionment frequently asked questions.](http://www.census.gov/topics/public-sector/congressional-apportionment/about/faqs.html)

questionText: What is apportionment?
answerMD: Apportionment is the process of dividing the 435 memberships, or seats, in the U.S. House of Representatives among the 50 states based on the apportionment population counts from the decennial census. For more information, please see [apportionment frequently asked questions.](http://www.census.gov/topics/public-sector/congressional-apportionment/about/faqs.html)

questionText: How often are the Section 203 Language Determinations published?
answerMD: Section 203(b) of the Voting Rights Act as amended prescribes that the director of the Census Bureau shall make these determinations **every 5 years**, based on the most current population estimates derived from the American Community Survey (ACS) along with relevant census data.

questionText: What is the universe of the recent mover questions in the American Housing Survey (AHS)� people who have moved in the past 12 months or since the previous survey?
answerMD:
*   In the national survey, during the interview (and hence for the microdata), we collect data on people moving in since the previous interview. However, for the summary tables, the universe is moves the past 12 months. Therefore, the answer is ‘both:' 2 years in the dataset, but 12 months in the summary tables.
*   In the metropolitan survey datasets, only people who moved within the past two years are flagged as recent movers—not all people who moved since the previous survey. (The time between surveys of the same metro area is longer than two years.)

questionText: Why doesn�t the distribution of monthly housing cost for owners in the summary tables match the distribution of the ZSMHC variable in the American Housing Survey (AHS) public use file (PUF)?
answerMD: The summary tables do not include the cost of maintenance (CSTMNT), while ZSMHC does. The summary tables show the median cost including maintenance as a separate row.

questionText: Can I compare 2020 Census data and American Community Survey data?
answerMD: Yes, data users can compare 2020 Census data with estimates from the American Community Survey. Data users should keep in mind the differences between the two sources. For example, the American Community Survey includes sampling error, whereas the decennial census does not.

questionText: How is a differentially private system different from the Census Bureau’s traditional disclosure avoidance techniques?
answerMD: The disclosure avoidance techniques that were used in the 2010 Census and in the American Community Survey rely on “swapping” characteristics in the underlying data between a subset (millions) of households in different geographic areas. In this era of Big Data, these methods are insufficient. Were we to use our prior disclosure avoidance techniques, the amount of noise we would have to inject into the data to comply with our statutory confidentiality obligations would make census data unfit for most uses. With the current method, the noise is added to the statistics in the tables themselves. This allows the U.S. Census Bureau to precisely control the amount of noise that we add. By documenting the properties of this noise, we can help data users determine if published estimates are suitable for their specific applications. We call this assuring “fitness for use.” Documenting the impact of this noise is similar to the way we provide margins of error for our current statistical products. For the same level of protection, a differentially private 2020 dataset will be significantly more accurate than datasets produced using our prior disclosure avoidance methods.

questionText: How is the Census Bureau addressing data fitness for redistricting purposes?
answerMD:
The Census Bureau recognizes the unique importance of decennial census data for the fair and equitable allocation of political representation at all levels of government. As such, we consider the use of census data products for redistricting and for enforcement of the Voting Rights Act to be among the highest priority uses of census data. We are committed to ensuring that the 2020 Census data products will be sufficiently accurate to support these important uses.

Final decisions about which data elements will be held “invariant” (reported exactly as enumerated without noise) in the 2020 Census Data Products will be made by the Census Bureau’s Data Stewardship Executive Policy Committee (DSEP) in September 2020. [In the 2010 Demonstration Data Products](https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/decennial-census/2020-census/planning-management/memo-series/2020-memo-2019_25.html), the following elements were held invariant: (1) total population at the state level; (2) number and type of group quarters facilities at the block level; and (3) number of housing units at the block level.

See also:  [Disclosure Avoidance and the 2020 Census](https://www.census.gov/about/policies/privacy/statistical_safeguards/disclosure-avoidance-2020-census.html?)

questionText: Why was the 2017 Puerto Rico Census Test stopped?
answerMD: In order to mitigate funding uncertainty risk and ensure readiness for the 2018 End-to-End Census Test, the Census Bureau adjusted its testing plans to stop the planned 2017 field testing operations in the Puerto Rico municipios of Carolina, Loíza, and Trujillo Alto (originally planned as the 2017 Puerto Rico Census Test). These sites will be considered for potential inclusion in the 2018 End-to-End Census Test.

questionText: Why did the 2017 Census Test plans change?
answerMD: In order to mitigate funding uncertainty risk and ensure readiness for the 2018 End-to-End Census Test, the Census Bureau adjusted its testing plans to stop the planned fiscal year 2017 field testing operations on the Standing Rock Reservation in North Dakota and South Dakota and the Colville Reservation and Off-Reservation Trust Land in Washington State (originally planned as part of the 2017 Census Test). However, the national sample self-response test scheduled as part of the 2017 Census Test will continue as planned, with an April 1, 2017 Census day.

questionText: I completed the American Community Survey last year, so why do I need to complete it again?
answerMD:
The U.S. Census Bureau conducts many different surveys and or censuses. So, it’s possible you completed one of our others surveys like the decennial census.

The American Community Survey (ACS) is different from the decennial or once-a-decade count of the U.S. population. The ACS collects data yearly about our education, housing, jobs and other characteristics, showing how we live and the economic and social needs of our communities. 

 If your household received the American Community Survey, you must complete it _and_ the decennial census. Your responses to both are important and required by law (Title 13, U.S. Code).    
It’s very unlikely you’ll receive an ACS more than once every five years. The reason: We mail our surveys to addresses not individuals and it’s rare an address would be selected more often: 

However, individuals who move to a new address may receive the survey again in that five-year period.

questionText: Where can I get data about public sector jobs to complement the data in the economic census?
answerMD:
The [Census of Governments](http://www.census.gov/govs/cog/), conducted for the same years as the economic census, summarizes employment in state and local governments. Counts of federal employees by state (even-numbered years only) theoretically complete the picture. There is a small amount of overlap: the economic census includes state-run liquor stores (retail trade) and government-owned hospitals (health care and social services).

A special tabulation from Census 2000, the [Census Transportation Planning Package](http://www.census.gov/mp/www/spectab/specialtab.html) (CTPP), shows employment numbers by sector by county, place, census tract, and traffic zone of work. The sector totals will include the agriculture and public administration sectors not included in the economic census, as well as the public school and social service agency employment not covered in the economic census or County Business Patterns.

For counties and cities of 100,000 or more population, the Census 2000 Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) [special tabulation](http://www.census.gov/eeo2000/) shows detailed occupation by industry (generally 3-digit NAICS), including 13 categories outside the scope of the economic census.

questionText: What type of information is available for the older population?
answerMD:
The U.S. Census Bureau produces annual [age data](http://www.census.gov/population/www/socdemo/age.html) for the nation, states, and counties showing the U.S. population at all ages.

In addition, the [American FactFinder](http://factfinder.census.gov/home/saff/main.html?_lang=en) provides age data from the [American Community Survey](http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/DatasetMainPageServlet?_program=ACS&_submenuId=&_lang=en&_ts=) and the [1990 and 2000 Censuses](http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/DatasetMainPageServlet?_program=DEC&_submenuId=datasets_2&_lang=en&_ts=) on social and economic characteristics (e.g., age, sex, race, ethnicity, and educational attainment) for many levels of geography. You may also be interested in:     

*   _[The Geographic Distribution and Characteristics of Older Workers](http://lehd.did.census.gov/led/library/profiles.html)._ Series of reports on older workers.
*   [Census 2000 Briefs and Special Reports](http://www.census.gov/population/www/cen2000/briefs.html) 
*   [International Data Base](http://www.census.gov/ipc/www/idb/). Age data for 224 countries and areas of the world.

questionText: Will the Census Bureau meet the December 31, 2020, statutory deadline?
answerMD: The Census Bureau is working hard to process the data in order to deliver complete and accurate state population counts as close to the December 31, 2020, statutory deadline as possible.

questionText: Does the Census Bureau designate Opportunity Zones or release data for them?
answerMD: No, Opportunity Zone are created by the U.S. Department of the Treasury and the Internal Revenue Service.  They use census tracts as their basic geographic unit, but the Census Bureau has no input into this program.  For more information and to find qualified tracts go to: [https://www.cdfifund.gov/Pages/Opportunity-Zones.aspx](https://www.cdfifund.gov/Pages/Opportunity-Zones.aspx)

questionText: How do I determine if my geographic area of interest is urban or rural?
answerMD:
The U.S. Census Bureau defines urban and rural at the block level. Therefore, geographic entities, including cities, towns and census tracts, may be urban (located wholly within an urban area), rural (located entirely outside an urban area), or contain both urban and rural territory (only the densely settled portion of the city is within an urban area).

To determine whether a census block is urban or rural, download the [TIGER/Line Shapefile](https://www.census.gov/geographies/mapping-files/time-series/geo/tiger-line-file.html) for blocks. Then open the .dbf file in a program that reads tabular data and look at the U/R column.

You may use the [Mable Geocorr](http://mcdc.missouri.edu/applications/geocorr2018.html) tool from the Missouri Census Data Center to determine if an entity larger than a block is urban or rural. Choose a state, enter the geographic entity, for example, ‘County’ in the left hand column and ‘Urban-Rural Portion’ in the right hand column. Scroll down and click Run Request. You many view the html output and download the .csv output.

questionText: How will the U.S. Census Bureau use the information collected by the ACS?
answerMD: The Census Bureau uses the information you provide to the American Community Survey (ACS) for statistical purposes only and cannot publish or release information that would identify you and your household. Your information will be used in combination with information from other households to produce statistics for your community. These statistics are available to the public, but Title 13, United States Code (U.S.C.), prohibits the Census Bureau from giving or selling your personal information to anyone, including companies, other federal agencies, and law enforcement.

questionText: In the AESDirect Shipment Manager, why are there multiple rejections showing under one Shipment Reference Number (SRN)?
answerMD: AESDirect will show all previous entries for a particular filing based on the SRN. The Count (History View) feature allows users to view and track every action taken on a particular filing. The most recent submission in the History View will show the current status of the shipment.

questionText: The system is giving me a 970 Fatal Error and will not allow me to process my shipment, what is wrong?
answerMD:
The 970 Fatal Error is a supplemental error informing your of another fatal error on the shipment. Please identify the addtional fatal error that you are receiving. Refer to [Appendix A](https://www.cbp.gov/document/guidance/aestir-appendix-commodity-filing-response-messages) of the Automated Export System Trade Interface Requirements (AESTIR) for the reason and resolution to the various error messages.

If you cannot resolve this issue, please contact the Trade Data Collection Branch at 1-800-549-0595, then choose option 1, or send email to askaes@census.gov.

questionText: What is redistricting?
answerMD: The 2020 Census asks questions that collect information necessary for redistricting. Redistricting is the redrawing of boundaries for the areas that are used to determine where people elect their representatives to the U.S. House of Representatives, state legislature, county or city council, school board, and so forth. Law (Public Law 94-171) requires that the redistricting data be delivered to state officials within one year of Census day or no later than April first, 2021.

questionText: How will the new disclosure avoidance methods affect the availability of data?
answerMD:
Ultimately, we must make decisions about whether the level of detail we currently provide is sustainable given external privacy threats.

Even with the new safeguards, protecting privacy requires us to restructure many of the statistical tables that we publish. We are working with data users to help us identify the levels of precision and geography that are critical to providing data that meet their data needs.

However, it also allows us in many cases to publish data that, without the new methods, would have been suppressed. The Opportunity Atlas ([opportunityinsights.org/data/](https://t.co/2fk8wJIPgD)) is a great example of a database using the new methods. It publishes ”tract-level” data on intergenerational mobility by race and gender. The detail in these data would be impossible without formal privacy.

questionText: What is included in the grocery store estimate?
answerMD:
The grocery store estimate represents total receipts of stores that are primarily engaged in the sale of groceries. The estimate includes the value of all items sold by grocery stores and may include receipts for drugs, gasoline, stationery, beer and wine, household items, etc. sold by the grocery store. A retail operation is classified based on its major source of receipts.

For more information, visit the [Monthly and Annual Retail Trade](http://www.census.gov/retail/index.html) website.

questionText: What do I do if the address listed on the form is incorrect?
answerMD: Cross out the old information and write in the correct information and return with your reported data via mail or type the corrected information [online](http://bhs.econ.census.gov/BHS/UFO/index.html) and submit with your data.

questionText: What data were used to conduct the 2021 Section 203 Language Determinations?
answerMD: The 2021 determinations are based on the 2015–2019 ACS 5-year estimates. We use a statistical technique called modeling to strengthen the ACS estimates to make the determinations, instead of using only direct estimates. More information about how we use this technique is available in the [executive summary](https://www2.census.gov/programs-surveys/decennial/rdo/about/voting-rights-determination/2021_Section203/Sec203_ExecSummary2021_v3.pdf).

questionText: Did the COVID-19 pandemic affect the release of redistricting data?
answerMD: The COVID-19 pandemic and prioritizing the delivery of apportionment data delayed when we could provide the redistricting data.

questionText: What are the U.S. Census Bureau’s responsibilities for redistricting information? What are the states’ responsibilities for redistricting information?
answerMD: The Census Bureau’s responsibility is to provide population counts for the geographic areas the states need to accomplish their redistricting.  States are responsible for legislative redistricting.

questionText: How far back does the data go?
answerMD:
The earliest data on data.census.gov is from the 2000 Census. We are focusing our efforts on migrating data that was previously available on American FactFinder to data.census.gov, and preparing for new data releases (e.g. 2020 Census).

In the future, we may consider the possibility of adding more historical data.

Email us at [census.data@census.gov](mailto:census.data@census.gov) for any questions or comments you may have.  For more guidance on data availability and using data.census.gov, the Census API, and Microdata Access, visit our [Resources page](https://www.census.gov/data/what-is-data-census-gov.html).

questionText: Will the 2020 Census be the first census that publishes data protected by disclosure avoidance methods?
answerMD: The Census Bureau has used disclosure avoidance methods since they were first invented in the 1970s. For a comprehensive summary of the methods used for historical censuses, see Laura McKenna’s report “Disclosure Avoidance Techniques Used for the 1970 through 2010 Decennial Censuses of Population and Housing” at [www2.census.gov/ces/wp/2018/CES-WP-18-47.pdf](http://www2.census.gov/ces/wp/2018/CES-WP-18-47.pdf).

questionText: How will the new disclosure avoidance privacy system affect the availability of data?
answerMD:
Ultimately, we must make decisions about whether the level of detail we currently provide is sustainable given external privacy threats.   

Even with the new safeguards, protecting privacy requires us to restructure many of the statistical tables that we publish. We are working with data users to help us identify the levels of precision and geography that are critical to providing data that meet their data needs.  

See also:  [Statistical Safeguards](https://www.census.gov/about/policies/privacy/statistical_safeguards.html "Statistical Safeguards")

questionText: What data are being collected for the Group Quarters Enumeration for the 2018 Census Test?
answerMD: The type of data collected for the Group Quarters Enumeration for the 2018 Census Test are name, sex, date of birth, age on Census Day, Hispanic origin, race, and an alternate address where they live or stay when not at a facility.

questionText: How will data users be able to evaluate the output of the final 2020 Disclosure Avoidance System design?
answerMD: We are developing a set of metrics that will allow us to measure and share progress as we iteratively improve the 2020 DAS over the course of 2020. We are working with data user experts to define the metrics that will best help data users evaluate the data’s fitness for use in different use cases. This will allow us to identify and prioritize the iterative improvements that we will be making to the DAS over the remainder of the year. We are also exploring the idea of producing an updated version of the demonstration data product after release of the redistricting files. We will post additional versions of the 2020 DAS source code, including the final production version, to [GitHub.com/uscensusbureau](https://github.com/uscensusbureau), where two earlier versions are already available.

questionText: Why was the e-commerce sales estimate for the prior quarter revised?
answerMD:
The e-commerce sales estimate for the prior quarter was revised to reflect additional response data.

For more information, visit the [Monthly and Annual Retail Trade](http://www.census.gov/retail/index.html) website.

questionText: How long will the Group Quarters Advance Contact Operation interview with the GQ staff for the 2018 Census Test take?
answerMD: The GQAC operation interview for the 2018 Census Test will take approximately 10 minutes.

questionText: What is the decennial census?
answerMD: The decennial census counts each person in the country, where they live on April 1, every 10 years ending in zero. The last census was in 2010, and the next census will be in 2020.

questionText: Why are the monthly retail estimates revised?
answerMD:
The monthly retail sales and inventory estimates are benchmarked each year to reflect the results from the latest Annual Retail Trade Survey and the latest Economic Census.

For more information, visit the [Monthly and Annual Retail Trade](http://www.census.gov/retail/index.html) website.

questionText: Did the Census Bureau alter the Advance Monthly Retail Trade and Food Services Survey seasonal adjustment options for August, September, or October 2005?
answerMD:
No. The review of the seasonal adjustment output and diagnostics did not indicate that adjustments to the options were necessary for these months.

For more information, visit the [Monthly and Annual Retail Trade](http://www.census.gov/retail/index.html) website.

questionText: Did the Census Bureau alter the Monthly Retail Trade Survey seasonal adjustment options for August and September 2005?
answerMD:
No. The review of the seasonal adjustment output and diagnostics did not indicate that adjustments to the options were necessary for these months.

For more information, visit the [Monthly and Annual Retail Trade](http://www.census.gov/retail/index.html) website.

questionText: Does the U. S. Census Bureau produce information on the subject of overpopulation?
answerMD:
The U. S. Census Bureau is a statistical agency within the federal government which collects and evaluates data on the U.S. population and population growth. We do not, however, address political issues, such as overpopulation, nor suggest policies based on our data. You might wish to contact non-federal government organizations which may have information on overpopulation, such as:

*   Zero Population Growth, 1400 16th Street, N.W., Suite 320, Washington, DC 20036. (202) 332-2200
    
*   Population Reference Bureau, 1875 Connecticut Ave., N.W., Suite 520, Washington, DC 20009. (202) 483-1100
    
*   The Urban Institute, 2100 M Street, N.W., Washington, DC 20037. (202) 833-7200
    
*   Population Action International, 1300 19th Street, N.W., Suite 200,Washington, DC 20036. (202) 659-1833
    
*   Population Environment Balance, 2000 P Street, N.W., Suite 600, Washington, DC 20036. (202) 955-5700
    
*   The Population Institute, 107 2nd Street, N.E., Washington, DC 20002. (202) 544-3300.

questionText: Does the U.S. Census Bureau provide how many U.S. citizens are 18 years and over?
answerMD:
Citizens of the United States includes people born in the U.S., Puerto Rico, a U.S. Island Area (American Samoa, Guam, The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI), and the U.S. Virgin Islands), or abroad of an American (U.S. citizen) parent, as well as foreign-born people who obtained U.S. citizenship through naturalization.

The Census Bureau provides U.S. citizenship by age on an annual basis from the following sources:

*   The American Community Survey (ACS) 1-year estimates provide data for the U.S., states, and all geographic areas of 65,000 or more population.  Table [B05003](http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/DTTable?_bm=y&-geo_id=01000US&-ds_name=ACS_2009_1YR_G00_&-_lang=en&-mt_name=ACS_2009_1YR_G2000_B05003&-format=&-CONTEXT=dt) provides age by sex by citizenship status for the for the population under and over 18 years of age for the U.S. 
*   The Current Population Survey provides reports and tables on the [Foreign-Born Population in the U.S.](http://www.census.gov/population/www/socdemo/foreign/datatbls.html)  From this site you can obtain foreign-born population for the U.S. and naturalized citizenship by age (and other characteristics) both current and historical.  [Annual Data Tables](http://www.census.gov/population/www/socdemo/foreign/cps2009.html) for 2009, Tables 1.1 through 1.16, provide our most current data on nativity and U.S. citizenship status.
*   Census 2000 and [Summary File 3 and 4](http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/DatasetMainPageServlet?_program=DEC&_submenuId=datasets_1&_lang=en) provides data on citizenship for all geographies in the U.S. 
*   [Public Use Microdata Samples (PUMS)](http://www.census.gov/main/www/pums.html) files contain data for both ACS and Census 2000.

questionText: Do you have a list of governments in the U.S.?
answerMD: Yes.  The [Governments Integrated Directory](http://harvester.census.gov/gid/gid_07/options.html) is the master list of all governments in the U.S.  It contains the names, unique identification codes, and other reference information about all local governments and dependent school systems in the U.S., as enumerated for the 2007 Census of Governments.

questionText: How can a news reporter submit a question to the Census Bureau?
answerMD:
Reporters in the working press (print, radio, or TV) should click on the **Ask a Question** tab at the top of this page, enter "pio media" in the "Subject" field, type the question in the "Question" field, and then click on "Continue."

The system will suggest several answers but you may submit your question by clicking on the "Finish Submitting Question" button. We know reporters face tight deadlines, so a staff member will get back to you within one business day.

questionText: How does the Census Bureau determine the order of states for releasing the data?
answerMD:
This following link lists each state and their redistricting deadlines. The states' deadlines provide a general guide that the Census Bureau uses when determining the possible order of release. Public Law 94-171 requires that data for all states be released to the state leadership by April 1, or one year after census day.  
  
See [http://www.census.gov/rdo/about\_the\_program/additional\_redistricting\_resources.html](http://www.census.gov/rdo/about_the_program/additional_redistricting_resources.html) and then click on the link for the 2010 State Redistricting Profiles hosted by the Minnesota Senate.

questionText: So far, it looks like the Census Bureau is releasing data for four states at a time... is that the expected rate of release going forward?
answerMD: The number of states released each week will vary, depending on how quickly the data are checked and when we receive confirmation from the state leadership that they have received it. Each week, we will put out an advisory listing the states that are anticipated for the week ahead. Once we have shipped the data to each state, we will issue another advisory to let the media and public know. Generally within 24 hours of shipping the data, we will receive confirmation from the states and be able to release the data.

questionText: In the 2015 Census Test, what is "Census Day?"
answerMD: For purposes of the 2015 Census Test, respondents should fill out the census questionnaire based on the people of the household as of April 1, 2015. Even if you are filling out the form a few days before or a few days after the April 1 "Census Day," base your answers about people living in your household on April 1, 2015.

questionText: County Business Patterns: Why do letters appear in some of the columns instead of numbers?
answerMD:
The Census Bureau uses disclosure symbols to replace data that is suppressed to protect the confidentiality and the integrity of the published data. For example, when data does not meet publication standards, the value is replaced with an â€˜S'. When data could potentially identify an individual business, the value is replaced with a â€˜D'. In cases where employment data are suppressed, a range of the number of employees is shown instead. Employment flags for these ranges are represented by the letters 'a' through 'm'.  Refer to the [CBP Definitions](http://www.census.gov/econ/cbp/definitions.htm "cbp definitions") webpage for a complete list of the employment flag values.  
  
Also, since 2007, all CBP data have been published using the Noise Infusion Method, which applies an associated noise flag that indicates whether a cell has low or medium Noise relative to other data cells. Refer to the CBP [How the Data are Collected](http://www.census.gov/econ/cbp/methodology.htm "how the data are collected") webpage for an explanation of the Noise Infusion Method used to protect published data.  
  
  
Keywords: CBP

questionText: Does the Census Bureau have any data on the number of college students who receive financial aid?
answerMD:
[Data from the Survey of Income and Program Participation](http://www.census.gov/population/www/socdemo/sch_cost.html) examines full-time postsecondary students, the characteristics of the schools they attended, and the cost and finances associated with their education. 

Tabulations from previous years are available on the web site.

questionText: What is the Census in Schools program?
answerMD:
The Census in Schools (CIS) program strives to increase awareness of the U.S. Census Bureau's activities and the use of the census data in classrooms. CIS provides user-friendly products that incorporate real-world information, tailored for the needs of educators and students. CIS prepares standards-based, supplementary lesson plans for grades K thru 12 and they are designed to build geographical and statistical literacy. 

We will be adding and updating information, as we get closer to the 2010 Census.

*   [State Facts for Students](http://www.census.gov/schools/facts/) was designed to help students in grades 3-5 learn about their state as they collect, organize, analyze, map, and graph a variety of information.  They have the opportunity to examine data about kids their age, as well as a variety of other facts selected to appeal to young students.  
      
    
*   [Census in Schools](http://www.census.gov/schools/). New and improved Web site has information for students as well as educators.   
      
    
*   [Census for Kids](http://www.census.gov/schools/census_for_kids/index.html). Explore coloring pages, quizzes, word finds, and more!

questionText: Where can I find data on a certain topic?
answerMD:
If you know that the census has the information you want but you can't find the right table, you can use the [Search](http://factfinder2.census.gov/faces/nav/jsf/pages/searchresults.xhtml) function on the American FactFinder main page tool bar. If you don't know what data the economic census has, or how it is organized, you can go to the [Finding Data](http://www.census.gov/econ/census07/www/finding_data/) section on the 2007 Economic Census Web site for tips and tools.

It helps to know that the tables are organized by industry and geographic area. Generally the geographic area tables have basic data items like number of establishments, sales, payroll and number of employees by industry. Other data items, like detailed products and services, and industry-specific inquiries, and data sorts other than industry and geography (like size, and legal form of organization) are in industry or subject reports.

questionText: In M3, why is the non-defense capital goods excluding aircraft and parts series missing from the M3 durable good report?
answerMD: In the conversion to the NAICS classification system, the capital goods series was redefined and no longer includes aircraft parts.  This change is because parts are not considered capital goods, only the finished product, in this case airplanes, is a capital good.  This definition change meant that to exclude aircraft and part would be incorrect.  Instead, one should only exclude the aircraft portion.  We are not in a position to publish just the aircraft piece on the durable goods report so the exclusion isn't possible either.

questionText: In the original (unadjusted) series, this year's April value is larger than the March value. But the seasonally adjusted series shows a decrease from March to April this year. What does this discrepancy mean?
answerMD: This difference in direction can happen only when the seasonal factor for April is larger than the seasonal factor for March, indicating that when the underlying level of the series isn't changing, the April value will typically be larger than the March value. This year, the original series' April increase over the March value must be smaller than usual, either because the underlying level of the series is decreasing or because some special event or events abnormally increased the March value somewhat, or decreased the April value somewhat. (When trading day or moving holiday effects are present and are being adjusted out, other explanations are possible.)

questionText: I watch the economy closely. Where can I find the release dates for the official economic indicators?
answerMD:
The Census Bureau issues a number of economic indicator reports that economists and policymakers watch to monitor the nation's economic well-being.

The [Census Economic Briefing Rooms](http://www.census.gov/cgi-bin/briefroom/BriefRm) page contains links to all indicator reports. There are also [release schedules](http://www.census.gov/epcd/econ/www/indijun.htm) for the reports on this page.  Our indicators include:

questionText: Nonemployer Statistics: Why do letters appear in some of the columns instead of numbers?
answerMD: The Census Bureau uses disclosure symbols to replace data that is suppressed to protect the confidentiality and the integrity of the published data. When data does not meet publication standards, it is replaced with an 'S'. When data could potentially identify an individual business, it is replaced with a 'D'. Also, since 2007, all Nonemployer data have been published with an associated noise flag that indicates whether a cell has low or medium Noise applied relative to other data cells. Refer to the Nonemployer [Methodology](http://www.census.gov/econ/nonemployer/methodology.htm%20 "Methodology") page for an explanation of the Noise Infusion Method used to protect published data.

questionText: Why aren't the Latest Wholesale Reports for the current month or current year?
answerMD: The collection of monthly data doesn't begin until the month ends.  While companies are requested to provide data within the first 10 business days, it usually takes at least 4 weeks to obtain an acceptable response level.  Processing and analyzing overlap this collection period and it takes an additional 5 business days to finalize the report. Preliminary MWTS estimates are typically published approximately 45 days after the reference month. Final estimates are published approximately 75 days after the reference month. The collection of AWTS data doesn't begin until 3 or 4 weeks after the reference year ends.  While companies are requested to provide data within 30 business days, it usually takes at least 8 months to obtain an acceptable response level.  Processing and analyzing overlaps this collection period to some extent, but most occurs after data collection ends. The final estimates are typically released 13-16 months after the reference year has ended. The most current reports are on the main page.

questionText: Why can't I get the annual total by summing the seasonally adjusted monthly values or by summing the annual rates for each month or quarter of the year and dividing by 12 or 4?
answerMD:
When seasonal adjustment is done by dividing the time series by seasonal factors (or combined seasonal-trading day-holiday factors) it is arithmetically impossible for the adjusted series to have the same annual totals as the unadjusted series (except in the uninteresting case in which the time series values repeat perfectly from year to year). "Benchmarking" procedures can be used to modify the adjusted series so as to force the adjusted series to have the same totals as the unadjusted series, but these procedures do not account for evolving seasonal effects or for trading day differences due to the differing weekday compositions of different years.

For more information, visit the [Monthly and Annual Retail Trade](http://www.census.gov/retail/index.html) website.

questionText: How do I find the New Residential Construction data released today at 8:30a.m., as I'm not able to see the current press release in pdf or excel posted to the website?
answerMD:
Both formats (PDF and Excel) of the New Residential Construction press release were posted to the website at 8:30 a.m. If you are having trouble viewing the press release, clear the cache of your internet browser.  
  
If you are still unable to view the current press release, please call the Residential Construction Branch on (301) 763-5160 and we will fax or email a copy to you

questionText: American FactFinder: How do I select geographies if they are not listed in the Reference Map or in the Advanced Search Geographies map tab's "Select Geographies" dropdown box?
answerMD: The Reference Map and the Advanced Search Geographies map tab's "Select Geographies" dropdown options will vary at specific zoom level(s).  The closer you zoom into an area, the more geography options you will see available to select from in the "Select Geographies" dropdown box. For example, census tracts are not a default geography option listed in the "Select Geographies" dropdown box if you are zoomed to the state or national level.  You will need to zoom closer in to at least the county level or lower for census tracts to display in the "Select Geographies" dropdown box.

questionText: How has the American Housing Survey (AHS) public use file (PUF) coded the variable REUAD (reason unit added to survey) over time? Have there been any systematic errors or complications?
answerMD:
1997-2007:  
  
The field representative was asked to enter the reason the unit was created (REUAD) for all cases that were not non-interviews and new to the sample in that year. Cases in the permit frame were automatically stored as new construction.  
  
The field representative chose from the following answer list (numbering started at 3)  
  
3\. New Construction  
4\. Manufactured/Mobile home moved in  
5\. House moved in  
6\. Building relisted due to structural changes  
7\. Unit created when original living quarters split into more units  
8\. Unit created when original quarters merged to fewer units  
9\. Conversion of nonresidential unit  
10\. Other, specify  
11\. Office use only  
  
Cases were edited to ensure that those in the permit frame were correctly assigned to new construction.  
  
2009:  
  
The universe for the question and the answer list remained the same as between 1997 and 2007.  
There were a large number of cases that were reported as "house moved in" due to a misunderstanding of the category. This category was meant for housing units that were physically moved onto the location. In 2009, this category was removed from the published answer list, and those cases that were in this category were moved to category 11.  
  
2011:  
  
In 2011, the national and metro samples were combined and both the universe and answer list available to field representatives were altered for REUAD. REUAD was only asked for units that were found during listing or the interview as additional or extra housing units on the property.  
  
The 2011 answer list available to the FR was the following:  
  
7\. Unit created when original living quarters split into more units  
8\. Unit created when original quarters merged to fewer units  
9\. Conversion of nonresidential unit  
10\. Other, specify  
  
Beginning in 2011, cases in non-permit issuing areas built since that area was last interviewed in the AHS were set to new construction (3 for new construction). Additional and extra units found during the interview process and new construction for units that were mobile homes were set to category 4 (for mobile home moved in). Permit sample cases and additional units were no longer pre-filled in the interview instrument but were instead edited to new construction during post-collection processing.  
  
Due to the nature of the combined sample, a large number of cases added for sample coverage improvement or other sampling reasons were set to category 11 after collection. This number is especially large because a number of the metro sample cases in this year were redesigned to fit updated geography and an entirely new sample was drawn for much of Los Angeles.  
  
2013:  
  
The question universe, answer list, and editing process was the same in 2013 as it was for 2011, but in 2013 an additional questionnaire was sent to the regional offices near the end of data collection to re-categorize REUAD responses that were set to a 10 (other) in the field. The questionnaire included the previously dropped categories from 2009 and earlier.

questionText: American FactFinder: For a Zip Code Tabulation Area (ZCTA), how do I find the 2010 population for a specific race group, Hispanic or Latino origin group, or American Indian and Alaska Native tribal grouping?
answerMD:
From the American FactFinder Main page:

*   Click "Advanced Search" and "Show me all" if prompted.
    
*   Click the "Topics" button (on the left side of the page) to expand the Topics list.
    
*   Click on People.
    
*   Then expand Basic Count/Estimate.
    
*   Click **Population Total**.
    
*   Close the Topics Search Box.
    
*   Click the "Geographies" button.
    
*   Select a geographic type from the dropdown list: **5-digit ZIP Code Tabulation Area**.
    
*   Select a state from the drop-down list.
    
*   Select one or more ZCTAs from the Geographies Search Box.
    
*   Click - **ADD TO YOUR SELECTIONS**.
    
*   Close the Geography Search Box.
    
*   Click the "Race and Ethnic Groups" button.  
    
*   Enter a race or ethnic group (Asian, Black, Cherokee) in the text search box.
    
*   Click GO.  
    
*   Select the race or ethnic groups you are looking for from the Race and Ethnic Group Results.
    
*   Click **Add** to add to your selections.
    
*   Close the Race and Ethnic Groups Search Box.  
    
*   Make a Selection from the Search Results.  To do this, either:
    

*   Place a checkmark in the box next to them and click "View" or click "Download".
    
*   Click the table name.

questionText: Do you have any information on the Census Bureau's Privacy Impact Assessments?
answerMD: Yes.  Consistent with the objectives of the E-Government Act and in the spirit of our privacy principle of openness, the Census Bureau is releasing to the public our [Privacy Impact Assessments (PIAs)](http://www.census.gov/po/pia/).  Privacy Impact Assessments are required by the E-Government Act of 2002 whenever a federal agency is "developing or procuring information technology... or initiating a new collection of information... in an identifiable form...." The purpose of a Privacy Impact Assessment is to ensure there is no collection, storage, access, use or dissemination of identifiable personal information (and for some organizations, business information) that is not both needed and permitted. [View the inventory of the PIAs](http://www.census.gov/po/pia/).

questionText: When will the American Community Survey (ACS) use the newest Congressional Districts boundaries?
answerMD: Visit the [Geography Boundaries by Year](https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/acs/geography-acs/geography-boundaries-by-year.html) page on the American Community Survey (ACS) website to learn more about when the ACS will use particular Congressional District boundaries. You can also view the Congressional District [Reference Maps](https://www.census.gov/geographies/reference-maps.html) on the Geography website.

questionText: In the American Community Survey (ACS) data products, I see "*****" in the margin of the error column. The footnote tells me that this is a controlled estimate. What does this mean?
answerMD: Controlled estimates are not subject to sampling variability because they are made to conform to official intercensal estimates from the Census Bureau's Population Estimates Program (PEP). The PEP annually produces estimates of totals by sex, age, race, and Hispanic origin that are controlled to be equal to population estimates by weighting areas, such as counties, incorporated places, and minor civil divisions (MCDs). Learn more about ACS weighting methodology in the [Design and Methodology Report](https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/acs/methodology/design-and-methodology.html) and the [Accuracy of the Data](https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/acs/technical-documentation/code-lists.html) documentation.

questionText: Were Russians counted as a distinct detailed group in the 2020 Census?
answerMD:
Yes. The U.S. Census Bureau has made considerable updates to the race and ethnicity code list for the 2020 Census based on extensive research and outreach over the past decade. “Russian” were included as a distinct detailed population group within the “White” racial category, whereas in the 2010 Census it was coded as a “White ethnic group, not elsewhere classified.” The Census Bureau included “Russian” codes as part of the draft 2020 Census code list within the 2018 Census Test Redistricting Data Prototype (see [technical documentation](https://www2.census.gov/programs-surveys/decennial/rdo/technical-documentation/2020Census/2018Prototype_PL94_171_TechDoc_v2.pdf?), Appendix D).

Hundreds of new codes have been added to reflect the ways that people self-identify. Examples of other newly coded groups include Sikh, Jordanian, and Ghanaian. These detailed data will be collected through a write-in option on the 2020 Census race question. The Census Bureau follows U.S. Office of Management and Budget [(OMB) standards](https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2016/09/30/2016-23672/standards-for-maintaining-collecting-and-presenting-federal-data-on-race-and-ethnicity) for classifying data on race and ethnicity.

questionText: Were Jordanians counted as a distinct detailed group on the 2020 Census?
answerMD:
Yes. The U.S. Census Bureau has made considerable updates to the race and ethnicity code list for the 2020 Census based on extensive research and outreach over the past decade. “Jordanian” were included as a distinct detailed Middle Eastern or North African population group within the “White” racial category, whereas in the 2010 Census it was coded as “Other Arab.” The Census Bureau included “Jordanian” codes as part of the draft 2020 Census code list within the 2018 Census Test Redistricting Data Prototype (see [technical documentation](https://www2.census.gov/programs-surveys/decennial/rdo/technical-documentation/2020Census/2018Prototype_PL94_171_TechDoc_v2.pdf?), Appendix D).

Hundreds of new codes have been added to reflect the ways that people self-identify. Examples of other newly coded groups include Russian, Sikh, and Ghanaian. The Census Bureau follows U.S. Office of Management and Budget [(OMB) standards](https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2016/09/30/2016-23672/standards-for-maintaining-collecting-and-presenting-federal-data-on-race-and-ethnicity) for classifying data on race and ethnicity.

questionText: Were Ghanaians counted as a distinct detailed group on the 2020 Census?
answerMD:
Yes. The U.S. Census Bureau has made improvements to the race and ethnicity code list for the 2020 Census. “Ghanaian” were included as a distinct detailed group within the “Black or African American” racial category, whereas in the 2010 Census it was coded as a “Black ethnic group, not elsewhere classified.” The Census Bureau included “Ghanaian” codes as part of the draft 2020 Census code list within the 2018 Census Test Redistricting Data Prototype (see [technical documentation](https://www2.census.gov/programs-surveys/decennial/rdo/technical-documentation/2020Census/2018Prototype_PL94_171_TechDoc_v2.pdf?), Appendix D).

The Census Bureau follows U.S. Office of Management and Budget [(OMB) standards](https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2016/09/30/2016-23672/standards-for-maintaining-collecting-and-presenting-federal-data-on-race-and-ethnicity) for classifying data on race and ethnicity.

questionText: Should I have completed both the 2020 Census and the American Community Survey?
answerMD: Yes.  You should have responded to both the 2020 Census and the American Community Survey.  For help with the American Community Survey, call 1-800-354-7271 or visit [https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/acs](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__www.census.gov_programs-2Dsurveys_acs&d=DwMFAw&c=qwStF0e4-YFyvjCeML3ehA&r=PfbgLPj-g2gXs7T1pLOn1-aPMmIMMG8Oz5xIhKmVSHQ&m=wD8oXsIpypges_FGinKTdJHddEB_UkUdrQWI4wmwcjc&s=XlHcQvCRj6j08v5mbI_YR1_MRH7D8sXk7Y45y3njbEk&e=)

questionText: How accurate are the coordinates in the TIGER/Line Shapefiles?
answerMD:
Coordinates in the TIGER/Line Shapefiles have six decimal places, but the positional accuracy of these coordinates may not be as great as the six decimal places suggest. The spatial accuracy varies with the source materials used. The Census Bureau cannot specify the spatial accuracy of feature changes added by its field staff or other map or digital sources. Thus, the level of spatial accuracy in the TIGER/Line Shapefiles makes them unsuitable for engineering problems, property transfers, or other uses that might require highly accurate measurements of the earth's surface.

More information on the spatial accuracy of the TIGER/Line shapefiles can be found in the [TIGER/Line Technical Documentation](https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/geography/technical-documentation/complete-technical-documentation/tiger-geo-line.html).

Note: No warranty, expressed or implied, is made with regard to the accuracy of the data in the TIGER/Line Shapefiles, and no liability is assumed by the United States Government in general, or the Census Bureau specifically, as to the positional or attribute accuracy of the data. The boundary information in the TIGER/Line Shapefiles is for statistical data collection and tabulation purposes only. Their depiction and designation for statistical purposes does not constitute a determination of jurisdictional authority or rights of ownership or entitlement and they are not legal land descriptions.

questionText: How often are statistical boundaries updated in TIGER?
answerMD:
Most statistical geographic boundaries are updated once a decade, either immediately before or in the years following each decennial census. The [Participant Statistical Areas Program (PSAP)](https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/decennial-census/about/psap.html) collects updates to statistical boundaries prior to the census so that the decennial data can be tabulated for the newly defined geographic areas. Entities covered under PSAP include census tracts, block groups, census designated places (CDPs), and census county divisions (CCDs). The updated boundaries for these areas and for tribal statistical areas, are included in the decennial releases of TIGER products.

Other statistical areas are delineated using data collected during a decennial census. These include ZIP Code tabulation areas (ZCTAs), urban areas, and public use microdata areas (PUMAs). While these entities are considered decennial geographies and are inserted into the decennial TIGER products, they are not released until one to two years after a decennial census.

Finally, core based statistical area (CBSAs) are defined by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) once a decade, based on the newly delineated urban areas, and are then updated annually. CBSAs include metropolitan and micropolitan statistical areas, combined statistical areas, metropolitan divisions, New England city and town areas (NECTAs), combined NECTAs, and NECTA divisions. New CBSA boundaries based on the revised definitions are released in TIGER products in years ending in three. Updates are then made annually based on the new definitions and are released in TIGER products in years ending in four through nine.

questionText: How often are legal boundaries in TIGER updated?
answerMD:
Most legal boundaries in TIGER are updated annually with the input of local participants through the [Boundary and Annexation Survey (BAS)](https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/bas.html). Entities covered under the BAS include incorporated places, governmental minor civil divisions, consolidated cities, governmental counties (and equivalent areas), and American Indian reservations and off-reservation trust lands. For these areas, public TIGER products include the boundaries that were legally in effect as of January 1 of the year the product was released. Note though that the BAS is a voluntary program and that the Census Bureau cannot guarantee that all updates to these legal areas are collected.\*  
  
Legal areas not covered by the BAS include, congressional districts, state legislative districts (SLDs), voting districts, and school districts. Congressional districts, SLDs, and voting districts are updated by state participants through the [Redistricting Data Program](https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/decennial-census/about/rdo.html). While the Congress changes every two years, congressional districts boundaries are generally only re-delineated once a decade, when redistricting occurs after each decennial census. TIGER products for the new congressional district boundaries usually become available in years ending in the number three and are posted as a special release. In some cases, states make corrections after the initial delineation that go into effect for the following Congresses. These corrections are included in the TIGER/Line shapefiles released in even years.  
  
State legislative districts are updated in TIGER every other year and are released in even years. After each decennial census, they are also released with the new congressional district boundaries early in the year ending in three as a special release.  
  
Voting districts are updated in TIGER once a decade so that decennial data can be tabulated for them and used in redistricting. New voting district boundaries are available in the decennial TIGER releases.

School districts are updated in TIGER every two years, through the [School District Review Program](https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/sdrp.html). New school district boundaries are included in the TIGER releases in even years.

Note: No warranty, expressed or implied, is made with regard to the accuracy of the data in the TIGER/Line Shapefiles, and no liability is assumed by the United States Government in general, or the Census Bureau specifically, as to the positional or attribute accuracy of the data. The boundary information in the TIGER/Line Shapefiles is for statistical data collection and tabulation purposes only. Their depiction and designation for statistical purposes does not constitute a determination of jurisdictional authority or rights of ownership or entitlement and they are not legal land descriptions.

questionText: Where can I get more information on the Foreign Trade Regulations (FTR)?
answerMD: The FTR can be found on the U.S. Census Bureau’s Web site located at <www.census.gov/foreign-trade/regulations/index.html>. Questions concerning the FTR may be directed to the Trade Regulations Branch at 800-549-0595 or via e-mail at <emd.askregs@census.gov>.

questionText: What are the responsibilities of the U.S. Principal Party in Interest (USPPI) in a routed export transaction?
answerMD: They are responsible for the following: Provide basic commodity information to the authorized agent for completing the EEI (Electronic Export Information)/AES record, including name, EIN, Schedule B number and value. Maintain documentation to support information provided to the forwarding or authorized agent. In a routed export transaction, the U.S. Principal Party in Interest is not required to provide the authorized agent with a power of attorney or written authorization, the Foreign principal party in interest will provide the power of attrney or written authorization.

questionText: Why did the 2020 Census list the White racial category first?
answerMD: The race categories on the 2020 Census were listed in order of population size. The 2020 Census race question listed the White racial category first because it is the largest racial population group in the United States.

questionText: > What plans does the Census Bureau have for adding a “Middle Eastern or North African” (MENA) category or making other changes or improvements to the questions on race and ethnicity in the American Community Survey and the decennial census?
answerMD: As the Census Bureau evaluates the results of the 2020 Census race and ethnicity data, our experts will determine next steps for making improvements to future questions and data on race and ethnicity to be used in the American Community Survey, decennial census, and other demographic surveys. These discussions will be done in consultation with the U.S. Office of Management and Budget, Federal experts, advisors, and stakeholders.

questionText: When did the American Community Survey (ACS) estimates begin using the 2018 Standard Occupational Classification (SOC) system for coding occupations?
answerMD: The American Community Survey started using the 2018 Standard Occupational Classification (SOC) system with the 2018 ACS data products (released in 2019). ACS data products from 2010 through 2017 used the 2010 SOC system. Lastly, 2005 through 2009 ACS data products used the 2000 SOC system. Detailed crosswalks between Census occupation and SOC codes are available on our [Industry and Occupation](https://www.census.gov/topics/employment/industry-occupation.html) webpage. Learn more about the Standard Occupational Classification on the [Bureau of Labor Statistics](https://www.bls.gov/soc/) website.

questionText: What does a "no" answer for the variable SAMEDU mean in the American Housing Survey public use file (PUF)?
answerMD:
It could mean that:  
  

*   The unit is the result of a conversion or merger since the previous survey
*   The interviewer went to the wrong unit in the previous survey
*   The current unit is a replacement mobile home (or, much less frequently, a replacement structure)
*   The address is a vacant mobile home site that was occupied in the previous survey
*   The address identifies a location that is now a type C noninterview

questionText: Are the CSA/CBSA codes on the building permit data disks defined in terms of the most recent definition or are the codes defined using the most recent CSA/CBSA for each annual permit period?
answerMD:
The building permit data are based on the definition of the metropolitan area at the time of release.

Example: The 1988 building permit data are based on the 1988 [Metropolitian Statistical Area (MSA)](http://www.census.gov/population/www/estimates/metroarea.html) definitions.

questionText: When are the apportionment population counts given to the President? To the Congress? To the states?
answerMD:
Title 13, U.S. Code requires that the apportionment population counts for each state be delivered to the President within 9 months of the census date, and it requires that the census date is April 1 of the census year. This means that the statutory deadline for delivering the counts to the President is December 31 of the census year. Amid COVID-19-related delays in data collection and data processing, the Census Bureau will deliver the apportionment population counts as close to the statutory deadline as possible.

According to Title 2, U.S. Code, within one week of the opening of the next session of the Congress in the new year, the President must report to the Clerk of the U.S. House of Representatives the apportionment population counts for each state and the number of representatives to which each state is entitled.

Also according to Title 2, U.S. Code, within 15 days of receiving the apportionment population counts from the President, the Clerk of the House must inform each state governor of the number of representatives to which each state is entitled.

For more information, please see [apportionent frequently asked questions.](http://www.census.gov/topics/public-sector/congressional-apportionment/about/faqs.html)

questionText: What did the 2020 Census Hispanic origin and race questions look like?
answerMD:
The 2020 Census used the required two separate questions (one for [Hispanic or Latino origin](https://2020census.gov/en/about-questions/hispanic-origin.html) and one for [race](https://2020census.gov/en/about-questions/2020-census-questions-race.html)) to collect the races and ethnicities of the U.S. population — following the [standards](https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/FR-1997-10-30/pdf/97-28653.pdf) set by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget (OMB) in 1997.

Figure. 2020 Census Question on Hispanic Origin
