More information about the 2020 Census questions on race and ethnicity is available on our [Additional Instructions for Respondents](https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/decennial-census/technical-documentation/questionnaires/2020/response-guidance.html) page.

questionText: What type of formats will the redistricting data be released in for state officials?
answerMD: On August 12, 2021, we will provide the redistricting data in the summary file format, one of the formats that state officials have received the last two decades. By September 30, 2021, we will provide the same data in an easier-to-use toolkit. The toolkit will include DVDs and flash drives with an integrated browsing software for official state recipients. Data will also be made available for the public on data.census.gov.

questionText: What data will the redistricting release contain?
answerMD:
The August data release will provide the first look at the demographic characteristics of the nation by state, county, city, all the way down to the census block level, including:

*   Race and ethnicity.
*   Population 18 years and over.
*   Occupied and vacant housing units.
*   People living in group quarters like nursing homes, prisons, military barracks and college dorms.

questionText: Who is included in the resident population counts?
answerMD:
The resident population counts include all people (citizens and noncitizens) who are living in the United States at the time of the census. People are counted at their usual residence, which is the place where they live and sleep most of the time.  
 

The resident population also includes military and civilian employees of the U.S. government who are deployed outside the United States (while stationed or assigned in the United States) and can be allocated to a usual residence address in the United States based on administrative records from the Department of Defense.  
 

The resident population counts for the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Island Areas are not included in apportionment calculations (because those areas do not have voting seats in the U.S. House of Representatives), but they are included in other data products.  
 

Note: The resident population counts are available down to the lowest levels of geography (i.e. census block), but only the state totals are used for apportionment. The more detailed resident population data are included in other census data products that are used for redistricting and many other purposes.  
 

For more information, please see [apportionment frequently asked questions.](http://www.census.gov/topics/public-sector/congressional-apportionment/about/faqs.html)

questionText: How is the apportionment calculated?
answerMD: The apportionment of seats in the U.S. House of Representatives is calculated every ten years using the method of equal proportions, according to the provisions of Title 2, U.S. Code. Congress decides the method used to calculate the apportionment. This method has been used in every census since the 1940 Census. The method computes "priority values" based on each state's apportionment population. For more information, please see [apportionment frequently asked questions.](http://www.census.gov/topics/public-sector/congressional-apportionment/about/faqs.html)

questionText: What is the purpose of Electronic Export Information (EEI)?
answerMD: The EEI is used for compiling the official U.S. export statistics for the United States and for purposes of enforcing U.S. export laws and regulations. The regulatory provisions for preparing and filing the EEI are contained in the Foreign Trade Regulations, Title 15, Code of Federal Regulations, Part 30.

questionText: The name of the country where I was born has changed. How should I answer the place of birth question on the ACS?
answerMD: When answering the place of birth question in the American Community Survey (ACS), try to use current boundaries for countries, not the boundaries at the time of your birth. For example, please specify whether you were born in Northern Ireland or the Republic of Ireland (Eire); North or South Korea; England, Scotland, or Wales (not Great Britain or the United Kingdom); and, if applicable, the particular country or island in the Caribbean (for example, Jamaica, not West Indies).

questionText: How do I complete the survey?
answerMD:
Click on the link in the text message to respond to the survey.  If we have not received a response from you, you may receive follow-up texts.  The survey closes after 10 days, so be sure to answer the survey as soon as you receive the text.

Only those who have been selected to participate can complete the survey.

questionText: Does the Census Bureau have data on the population in counties and cities during business hours?
answerMD:
Yes, the Census Bureau released, the first-ever data on the [Daytime Population for Cities and Counties](http://www.census.gov/Press-Release/www/releases/archives/population/005822.html).

The findings come from the first-ever U.S. Census Bureau estimates of the daytime population for all counties and more than 6,400 places across the country, based on Census 2000 data.

The concept of the daytime population refers to the number of people, including workers, who are present in an area during normal business hours, in contrast to the resident population present during the evening and nighttime hours. You can access data for the [daytime population](http://www.census.gov/hhes/commuting/data/daytimepop.html) on our web page.

questionText: What was the impact of altering the seasonal adjustment option (additive outlier adjustment) for the July 2005 data month?
answerMD:
The impacted industry group showed an increase from June. If the July value had been treated as typical, the program would have taken part of the increase to be a seasonal effect and would have adjusted the data in a way that would have brought the adjusted percent change from June to July closer to zero. The altered option we used determined the increase in this combined NAICS industry group to be out of the ordinary. As a result, the June to July percent change in the adjusted value was left further from zero.

For more information, visit the [Monthly and Annual Retail Trade](http://www.census.gov/retail/index.html) website.

questionText: When will the apportionment population counts be released to the public? Will they be posted on the Internet?
answerMD: Amid COVID-19-related delays in data collection and data processing, the Census Bureau will deliver the apportionment population counts as close as possible to the statutory deadline of December 31, 2020. When the counts are delivered to the President, they will also be disseminated to the public through a press release on the Internet. For more information, please see [apportionment frequently asked questions.](http://www.census.gov/topics/public-sector/congressional-apportionment/about/faqs.html)

questionText: How many shipments are displayed in the AESDirect Shipment Manager? Why can I only see the filings from the last 90 days?
answerMD:
The Shipment Manager displays 3 months of shipment data at a time. Showing more than 3 months of shipment data at a time would affect the performance of the application.  
 

If you want to see shipments older than 90 days, the "Show Filters" option allows users to conduct a custom search of up to 5 years by entering a date range of up to 90 days at a time. Keep in mind, the Shipment Manager will only display shipments filed through the AESDirect portal.

questionText: Is there a way to create special tabulations from the American Housing Survey (AHS) when the summary tables do not cross the rows and columns I need?
answerMD:
The AHS Table Creator data tool gives users the ability to create customized tables from the American Housing Survey without having to use the Public Use File (microdata). The tool allows users to select a table of predefined rows and cross tabulate it by over 18 different variables, which display as columns. Up to two variables may be chosen for any given table.  
  
The AHS also publishes downloadable microdata files (PUFs) that allow users to construct tables using individual survey responses. The files are available in SAS and CSV formats. Access the microdata files from the Data page of the Census Bureau AHS web site, [http://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/ahs/data.html](http://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/ahs/data.html).  
  
If users require additional assistance, HUD or Census analysts may be able to produce custom tabulations, particularly for Federal agencies. These requests are handled on a case-by-case basis. Tabulations will be run using the public use files, not the internal files, to avoid disclosure issues. Contact the American Housing Survey Branch at 1-888-518-7365 (toll free) or email ahsn@census.gov for data questions or assistance with special tabulations.

questionText: What types of enumeration methods are offered during the Group Quarters Advanced Contact operation for the 2018 Group Quarters and Service-Based Enumerations?
answerMD:
The types of enumeration methods offered during the GQAC operation for the 2018 GQE and SBE are the following:

*   **Electronic Response Data Transfer (eResponse)**: The GQ contact person will be provided with a unique User ID to submit census response data to a secure portal for each person who was living or staying at the facility on Census Day.
*   **In-Person Interview:** A Census Bureau worker will conduct a face-to-face, interview with each person who received services or was staying at the facility on Census Day. This option is available to both SBE GQs and non-SBE GQs.
*   **Drop Off/Pick Up of Questionnaire:** A Census Bureau worker will leave Census questionnaires with the GQ contact person for them to distribute to each person who received services or was staying at the facility on Census Day. Then, a Census Bureau worker will pick up the completed forms from the contact person on another agreed upon time.
*   **Facility Self-Enumeration:** A Census Bureau worker will swear in and train the GQ contact person, and leave a census questionnaire package to conduct the enumeration for each person who received services or was staying at the facility on Census Day. A Census Bureau worker will return to pick up the questionnaires at an agreed upon time. Only correctional and health care facilities can select this option.
*   **Paper Response Data Collection:** A Census Bureau worker will meet with the GQ contact person of the facility to obtain a paper listing of census response data for each person who received services or was staying at the facility on Census Day. Shelters and non-SBE GQs will be allowed to select this method.

questionText: What data are being collected for the Group Quarters Advance Contact operation for the 2018 Census Test?
answerMD: The type of data collected for the GQAC operation for the 2018 Census Test are the GQ address, contact information, population size, enumeration options, and the best date for conducting enumeration.

questionText: Why does the variable QFS1 (receipt of food stamps) have so many more missing values than QWELF (receipt of TANF and other welfare) in the American Housing Survey (AHS) public use file (PUF)?
answerMD: The universe for the food stamp question (QFS1) requires that the household make less than $25,000.  If the household makes more, the response to QFS1 is set to B.  There is no such universe restriction set for the QWELF question.  There should be very few missings in the datasets.

questionText: How did the American Housing Survey (AHS) get started?
answerMD:
The original motivation for the surveys came from the post-riot commissions in the late 1960s (Kaiser Committee and the Douglas Commission).  The organizing meeting for the AHS was held in June 1970 at the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) in Washington, DC.  Participants included representatives of all the major domestic agencies, including all Cabinet agencies: Labor; Health, Education and Welfare; Agriculture; Commerce (DoC); and of course, Housing and Urban Development (HUD).   
  
The proposal for an annual survey of the nation's housing stock, and of at least sixty metropolitan areas, to provide needed housing data on which to base housing and community development policies and programs between the decennial censuses, was a joint proposal from the Housing Division of the Bureau of the Census, DoC, and the Office of Economic and Market Analysis, HUD, each of which had the approval of their respective cabinet secretaries.  
  
Neither outside nor internal HUD data collection resources were seriously considered because only the Census Bureau had complete access to the confidential records of the decennial censuses from which the basic national and metropolitan samples were to be selected.   
  
In addition, the Bureau controls the confidential records of the building permit, housing starts, and housing completions surveys, which were to be used to update the decennial census sample in permit-issuing areas.  No other Federal agencies or outside, private, firms had the national resources or statistical and data processing capabilities to handle the amount of data expected to be collected.  
  
For years, HUD had engaged the Census Bureau to collect housing production and marketing data to fill gaps in the housing statistical picture.  In 1959, the HHFA, a HUD predecessor agency, commissioned the Bureau of Labor Statistics to collect data on new home sales.  
  
The work was transferred to the Census Bureau in 1963 because the data series fit nicely with the Construction Division's building permits and housing starts series.  In 1968, the Housing Completions Survey, funded by HUD and administered by Census, was added to the New Home Sales Survey.  In 1969, the Survey of Market Absorption of New Apartments piggybacked on the existing production and marketing surveys, but was carried out by the Census Housing Division instead of the Construction Division.  In 1972, HUD sponsored and funded the Survey of New Mobile Home Placements, administered by the Census Construction Division.  Given the firm working relationship between HUD and Census, Census was the obvious choice to conduct the AHS.  The AHS, begun in 1973, is the most prominent in a line of HUD-funded and directed surveys conducted by the Census Bureau.  
  
In 1970, OMB unanimously approved the HUD-Census proposal for the AHS and allocated adequate funds to the HUD research budget for transfer to Census to implement the survey.

questionText: American FactFinder: How do I find data for "all the counties in a state" or "all the census tracts in a state"?
answerMD:
*   Click  the "Advanced Search" button.
    
*   Click  the Geographies button (left side of the screen).
    
*   In the dropdown box select the smaller geography (for instance, counties)
    
*   In the second dropdown box select the state.
    
*   Select "All Counties within â€˜State'" and then click Add to Your Selections.
    
*   Your search results will update.
    
*   Close the Geographies window by clicking the close button on the top right.
    
*   Select a table by clicking on the blue hyperlink or by placing a check in the checkbox and clicking View. 
    

Learn how to use the Geographic Search method by viewing the [Geographic Search Tutorial](http://factfinder2.census.gov/help/en/tutorials/geographies_tut.htm "Geographic Search Tutorial") or the [Geographic Search Help Content](http://factfinder2.census.gov/help/en/searching_for_data/searching_by_categories/search_using_geographies/searching_by_geography_name.htm "Geographic Search Help Content").

questionText: Is the American Community Survey the same as the 2020 Census?
answerMD:
No, the American Community Survey is different from the 2020 Census.  
  
  
  
The American Community Survey shows how we live - our education, housing, jobs, and more. The American Community Survey provides information about the social and economic needs of your community every year.  
  
  
  
The census is conducted every ten years to provide an official count of the entire U.S. population to Congress.  
  
  
  
If you are selected for the ACS, you are required to complete it in addition to the 2020 Census.  Your answers will help provide local and national leaders with the information they need for planning and programs.

questionText: Why did the 2020 Census list the White racial category first?
answerMD: The race categories on the 2020 Census were listed in order of population size. The 2020 Census race question listed the White racial category first because it is the largest racial population group in the United States.

questionText: Why do state and county boundaries on Florida’s Gulf Coast extend nine miles into the water while its Atlantic boundaries only reach three miles into the water?
answerMD:
A 1960 Supreme Court decision mandated that the legal boundary of Florida extend nine miles into the water only on the Gulf of Mexico side of the state.

We updated the state and county TIGER/Line files to reflect the nine-mile Gulf boundary limit during the 2019 Boundary and Annexation Survey (BAS).

questionText: There were origin examples listed with each of the race and ethnicity categories on the 2020 Census questionnaire. Why did the Census Bureau decide to use these examples and not others?
answerMD:
The 2020 Census examples for each racial or ethnic group represent the largest population groups and the geographic diversity of each racial or ethnic group, as defined by the 1997 OMB standards. The examples were tested in our research last decade, beginning with the 2015 National Content Test and the 2020 Census designs were implemented in the 2018 Census Test.

More information about the 2020 Census questions on race and ethnicity is available on our Additional Instructions for Respondents page.

questionText: Why does the "Year Round" column of the summary tables not match a tabulation of the variable YRRND from the American Housing Survey (AHS) public use file (PUF)?
answerMD:
Despite the similarity of their names, the summary table column and the PUF variable are based on different concepts.  
  
In the report, "Seasonal Use" is based on how the unit is used, not how it is equipped. Essentially, seasonal units are those for which STATUS = 2-3 (URE, vacant) and VACANCY = 8-11 (seasonal summer, seasonal winter, seasonal other, migratory). Year-round units are all the rest.  
  
In the PUF, YRRND is determined by the unit's physical equipmentâ€”particularly whether it has heating equipment.  
  
Even if a unit is not suitable for year-round use, it may be used that way, particularly in warm parts of the country. Conversely, a unit may be suitable for year-round use but only used seasonally, as in a well-equipped vacation home in Maine.

questionText: How do I identify the householder in the person records in the American Housing Survey (AHS) public use file (PUF)?
answerMD:
To identify the householder, you need to use the REL variable. A REL value of 1 or 2 is the householder.  
  
Note also that the flat version of the data file organizes the data so that the householder is always the "first" person, the person whose characteristics would be identified with a 1, such as AGE1, SEX1, REL1, etc.  
  
In addition, all of the householder's person-record data are included in the NEWHOUSE file, in variables with the prefix "HH" (such as HHAGE, HHSEX, etc.). Thus, if all you want to do is to filter or tabulate your data based on the householder's characteristics, you can do that using NEWHOUSE alone, without having to link to PERSON or use the flat file.

questionText: How will the Census Bureau communicate to the public that this survey is not the decennial census?
answerMD: The questionnaire makes it clear to respondents that this is not the decennial census. The Census Bureau conducts many ongoing surveys throughout the decade, including for other federal agencies.

questionText: What is the difference between the Economic Census and the Economic Census of Island Areas?
answerMD: The Economic Census collects data from businesses with paid employees in nearly every industry in the private, non-farm economy, and every geographic area of the U.S. The Economic Census of Island Areas collects the same kind of data, but from Puerto Rico and other U.S. Island Areas.

questionText: There were origin examples listed with each of the race and ethnicity categories on the 2020 Census questionnaire. Why did the Census Bureau decide to use these examples and not others?
answerMD:
The 2020 Census examples for each racial or ethnic group represent the largest population groups and the geographic diversity of each racial or ethnic group, as defined by the [1997 OMB standards](https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/FR-1997-10-30/pdf/97-28653.pdf). The examples were tested in our research last decade, beginning with the [2015 National Content Test](https://www.census.gov/newsroom/press-kits/2017/nct.html) and the 2020 Census designs were implemented in the [2018 Census Test](https://www.census.gov/newsroom/press-kits/2018/2018-census-test.html).

More information about the 2020 Census questions on race and ethnicity is available on our [Additional Instructions for Respondents](https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/decennial-census/technical-documentation/questionnaires/2020/response-guidance.html) page.

questionText: Why didn’t the U.S. Census Bureau use a Middle Eastern or North African (MENA) category in the 2020 Census?
answerMD:
The U.S. Census Bureau collects race data in accordance with the 1997 Standards for Maintaining, Collecting, and Presenting Federal Data on Race and Ethnicity directed by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget (OMB). The Census Bureau, and all other Federal statistical agencies, must adhere to the 1997 OMB Standards.  
 

The 1997 OMB Standards define “White” as “A person having origins in any of the original peoples of Europe, the Middle East, or North Africa.” Therefore, any MENA responses, such as Egyptian or Lebanese, are classified as White. Responses are based on self-identification.  

  
The Census Bureau conducted extensive research and outreach this past decade, including the 2015 National Content Test: Race and Ethnicity Analysis Report, on how to improve race and ethnicity information collections so that these statistics better measure our nation’s population. This research identified that a combined race and ethnicity question with a dedicated MENA category is the optimal design for improving race and ethnicity data (in comparison to separate questions designs).  

  
While a separate “Middle Eastern or North African” (or MENA) response category was not included,  
detailed MENA responses were elicited, collected, and coded.  Per the 1997 OMB standards, MENA responses are classified as part of the White racial category.

questionText: Why did the 2020 Census use the two-separate questions format for the race and ethnicity categories?
answerMD:
The 2020 Census collects race and ethnicity data in accordance with the U.S. Office of Management and Budget (OMB) 1997 [Standards for Maintaining, Collecting, and Presenting Federal Data on Race and Ethnicity](https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/FR-1997-10-30/pdf/97-28653.pdf). The U.S. Census Bureau must adhere to the 1997 OMB standards.

The OMB standards require two separate race and ethnicity questions for self-response. The standards require the ethnicity question to be collected first before the race question.

The 1997 OMB standards require two minimum categories for data on ethnicity:

1.  Hispanic or Latino
2.  Not Hispanic or Latino

The 1997 OMB standards require five minimum categories for data on race:

1.  American Indian or Alaska Native
2.  Asian
3.  Black or African American
4.  Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander
5.  White

The decennial census [is required by Congress](https://www.congress.gov/bill/109th-congress/house-bill/2862) to use the Some Other Race category.

Additionally, the OMB standards encourage the collection of detailed responses, and to address this, new examples and write-in areas were added to the 2020 Census ethnicity question and race question to give respondents from all backgrounds the opportunity to self-identify their racial/ethnic identities in the 2020 Census. For the 2020 Census, we collected detailed responses for all major categories (Hispanic, White, Black or African American, Asian, American Indian or Alaska Native, Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander, and Some Other Race). In turn, this will provide the ability to produce detailed tabulations for myriad population groups in the United States, such as German, Lebanese, Mexican, Jamaican, Nigerian, Chinese, Navajo, Samoan, Brazilian, etc.

More information about the 2020 Census questions on race and ethnicity is available on our [Additional Instructions for Respondents](https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/decennial-census/technical-documentation/questionnaires/2020/response-guidance.html) page.

questionText: Is it possible to identify when a respondent completed the survey in the American Community Survey (ACS) Public Use Microdata Sample (PUMS) files?
answerMD: No, there is no variable in the PUMS files to identify the month (or season, school year, etc) when the respondent answered the American Community Survey. Only the year of survey completion is available.

questionText: What levels of geography are available for the 2020 Demographic Analysis and Post-Enumeration results?
answerMD:
The 2020 Demographic Analysis is available at the national level.  
The 2020 Post-Enumeration Survey results are available at the national and state levels (state and Puerto Rico results are scheduled for release summer 2022). The breakdowns by characteristics, such as demographic groups or census operations, are provided only for the national estimates, not the state estimates.

questionText: Some of the TIGER/Line Shapefiles don't show an accurate shoreline, what is the reason for this?
answerMD: This is because [TIGER/Line Shapefiles](https://www.census.gov/geographies/mapping-files/time-series/geo/tiger-line-file.html "TIGER/Line Shapefiles") contain the legal boundaries of the states, which generally extend three miles out to the ocean. A more accurate depiction of the coastline could be created by downloading our Area Hydrography (water) shapefile and overlaying it on our state shapefile. Another option is to download the [Cartographic Boundary Files](https://www.census.gov/geographies/mapping-files/time-series/geo/carto-boundary-file.html "2010 Cartographic Boundary files"), which are generalized files that end at the shoreline. Please note that since these files are generalized, they are not intended for large-scale thematic mapping. In addition, they should not be used for area measurements or geocoding.

questionText: What is the 2017 Census Test?
answerMD: The 2017 Census Test will allow the Census Bureau to study a variety of new methods and advanced technologies that are under consideration for the 2020 Census. The primary focus is to test the integration of operations and systems for self-response and the feasibility of collecting tribal enrollment information.

questionText: How big is the White population? Did it increase or decrease?
answerMD:
To frame the discussion of the racial and ethnic composition of the United States, we use the concepts of race alone, race in combination, and Hispanic origin by race. These concepts have been in place since the 2000 Census. In the 2020 Census we reported that, overall, 235.4 million people reported White alone or in combination with another group.  

In the 2020 Census, 204.3 million people identified as White alone (61.6% of all people living in the U.S.). Together with the 31.1 million people who identified as White in combination with another race group, the White alone or in combination population comprised 235.4 million people (71% of the total population). Although the White alone population decreased by 8.6% since 2010, the White in combination population saw a 316% increase during the same period. The White population remained the largest race or ethnicity group in the United States. 

Another way to examine data on race and ethnicity is to cross-tabulate Hispanic or Latino origin by race statistics. In 2020, the White alone non-Hispanic population was the most prevalent racial ethnic group in the United States, at 191.7 million people (57.8% of the total U.S. population).  

For more information: These concepts are emphasized in our August 12, 2021 Redistricting Press Conference video presentation, and in two accompanying America Counts stories: Improved Race and Ethnicity Measures Reveal U.S. Population Is Much More Multiracial and 2020 U.S. Population More Racially and Ethnically Diverse Than Measured in 2010.

questionText: Why didn’t the U.S. Census Bureau use a Middle Eastern or North African (MENA) category in the 2020 Census?
answerMD:
The U.S. Census Bureau collects race data in accordance with the 1997 [Standards for Maintaining, Collecting, and Presenting Federal Data on Race and Ethnicity](https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/FR-1997-10-30/pdf/97-28653.pdf) directed by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget (OMB). The Census Bureau, and all other Federal statistical agencies, must adhere to the 1997 OMB Standards. 

The 1997 OMB Standards define “White” as “A person having origins in any of the original peoples of Europe, the Middle East, or North Africa.” Therefore, any MENA responses, such as Egyptian or Lebanese, are classified as White. Responses are based on self-identification. 

The Census Bureau conducted extensive research and outreach this past decade, including the [2015 National Content Test: Race and Ethnicity Analysis Report](https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/decennial-census/decade/2020/planning-management/plan/final-analysis/2015nct-race-ethnicity-analysis.html), on how to improve race and ethnicity information collections so that these statistics better measure our nation’s population. This research identified that a combined race and ethnicity question with a dedicated MENA category is the optimal design for improving race and ethnicity data (in comparison to separate questions designs). 

While a separate “Middle Eastern or North African” (or MENA) response category was not included, detailed MENA responses were elicited, collected, and coded.  Per the 1997 OMB standards, MENA responses are classified as part of the White racial category.

questionText: Why did the 2020 Census increase the number of write-in responses collected and coded for race and ethnicity?
answerMD:
Our research after the 2010 Census found that people were reporting longer and more detailed responses to the questions. For the 2020 Census, we aimed to reflect more fully and accurately the complex details of how people identify their race and ethnicity. Based on further research, testing, and outreach throughout the past decade, we changed how we captured and coded responses for the 2020 Census Hispanic origin and race questions. For the 2020 Census, we increased the number of characters captured from 30 to 200, which allowed us to capture and fully recognize longer write-in responses.

More information about these improvements is available in the Improvements to the 2020 Census Race and Hispanic Origin Question Designs, Data Processing, and Coding Procedures blog.

questionText: Why does the internal point included in the gazetteer files and TIGER/Line shapefiles sometimes not fall exactly in the center of the entity?
answerMD: The Census Bureau calculates an internal point (latitude and longitude coordinates) for each geographic entity. For many geographic entities, the internal point is at or near the geographic center of the entity. For some irregularly shaped entities (such as those shaped like a crescent), the calculated geographic center may be located outside the boundaries of the entity. In such instances, the internal point is identified as a point inside the entity boundaries nearest to the calculated geographic center.
